2.23.19  3:40 am   i remember once during an enforced choir class (that everyone had to take if they were part of the music program) there was a guitar player who was super talented but he just couldnt sing at all. Teacher kept asking him to sing higher and he just sing louder hahaha, not sure if that was the face he made from frustrtion from the throat-ear disconnect, or from the confusion of his voice not sounding like the timbre of the piano so it being harder to try and imagine what that pitch would soung like in voice.. it was a nice transformaion to hear him sing later on, it was just something he never tried hard enough to break out of his knowledge/skill comfot zone. Do you have any tips for breaking as many walls as you can daily? Things we may never know we could learn unless we tried doing them. Do you think this is part of what it's all about, or it's a distraction from getting better in your field?  would they all help you in your field somehow? sounds l ike a multi-armed bandit situation, i want a marshmellow now instead of 10 later
2.23.19  3:35 am   Salad or bannanas?

2.22.19  10:38 pm   Hey Bill. One of my music teachers said that a good way to learn how to play a difficult song is to learn every measure, measure by measure, backwards. That way as you play, you go from less to more familiar measures as you play, rather than play things you know and on the way forget how to do the new stuff you just learned. What do you think about this method?

2.22.19  6:25 pm   2.21.19  7:03 pm do you think you'd say that your content is (at least partially) an exploration of the nature of good?

      i feel like i do that when i make stuff, trying to figure out what it means for something to be good, rather than trying to express myself or make a statement or whatever else people usually do art for (not that they are in opposition to exploring good, only that they aren't my primary drives), and i'm unsure if anyone else has that experience or not
